annotation.TEXT: I'll just intentionally game over here...
Also, the music changes, too.
That was a 9-line combo, which was worth 50 bonus points! (Just 50? Come on. A combo of that size is worth 300 in Tetris Blast, and it's easier to make such a combo there, too!)
Gee... I wonder how I should place these line pieces...
Your score goes up by 2! Just 2? That's it? Well, as you've seen in Puzzle mode, with chain reactions, combos of more than 4 lines are possible!
Oh! In this stage, a big bomb has already been formed for me! (However, you don't get +1 for any premade big bombs.)
Hello, and welcome back to Super Tetris 3. This time, I'll cover Sparkliss mode. I don't think it's quite as confusing as Magicaliss, but there are still some twists to it.

Ah, nuts! I missed a few blocks! However, when you're this close to winning, the game will help you out! Whenever there are fewer than ten total blocks on the field, your next piece will always consist entirely of bombs! (This is true in Tetris Blast as well.)
But, what about that big bomb? Well, let's complete a line with it and see what happens!
Okay, let's see how this works. Pay attention to the interior blocks that the explosions don't hit directly.
Also, don't worry about messing up. You can always retry a puzzle over and over until you get it right.
Looks tricky, but you're given only one piece, so it's probably very simple!
Ah, here's a much better example of the explosion enclosure clearing that I was talking about earlier. Pay attention to the dark blocks.
After every two stages, the background changes. Now we've got knights instead of dragons.
Ooh! They exploded! Yeah, those special blocks are bombs. If you've played Tetris Blast on the Game Boy, this will seem familiar.
Yes, there are! If you score a tetris...
...the range increases! For instance, with a double, the small bomb's range is 4.
You could end up with a few all-bomb pieces in a row, and it's helpful for making big bombs to clear the rest of the field with!
Oh, yeah. The spiked blocks apparently defy gravity.
Now, you're given a limited number of pieces to clear the board with. This one's simple enough.
In Puzzle mode, there are 100 stages to clear, but you can start on any stage. Since the first few stages are very simple, I think I'll start with... stage 7.
Okay, the goal of Sparkliss mode is to remove all of the blocks from the field.
Normally, a small bomb's range is 3 in all directions, but if you clear multiple lines at once...
I'm going to try putting together a huge combo! This will take some setting up...
Let's start with Contest mode.
Also, when you initially create a big bomb, you gain 1 point. Oh, yeah. I should cover how scoring works.
Any normal blocks hit by the explosion are removed, and any bombs hit by the explosion are detonated, which can cause huge chain reactions!
Let's see what happens if I do... this!

In Contest mode, you start each stage with 100 points (shown in the lower-left). It decreases by one with each piece you use. You have to clear the field before you run out of points. When you clear a stage, the remaining points are added to your overall score (lower-right), and you go to the next stage.
KA-BOOOOM!!!!!
Gotta keep the bombs' range in mind as I'm doing this...

If bomb explosions form an enclosed space, completely surrounding any blocks, those blocks will disappear. Enclosed bombs will also disappear this way, but they won't detonate if they vanish like that.
Now, I want to just go back to Contest mode for a moment here...
Hmm...? What are those different colored blocks down there for? Well, let's complete a line and find out!
Even if a puzzle looks complicated at first, there's probably an easy enough solution (at least in the early stages). Just try sticking the pieces where it looks like they'll fit best.
Also, here's a good example of a nice chain reaction, and how the explosions get larger with more cleared lines.
Trust me, there is a method to this madness!
Yeah! Mayhem! Mayhem! Mayhem! (Do we really need all those "Mayhem"s?)

The select button can be used during play to forfeit the game, which is handy if you know you screwed up and want to retry, or if you just want to quit playing. (You don't have to pause the game to do this. I did that by accident.)
Oh, yeah. Exclusive to Puzzle mode (I think...) are some special blocks. These spiked blocks at the bottom can't be removed, but you don't have to clear them to finish the stage.
KA-BOOOOOOMMM!!!!!
Once again, just like normal Tetris, you want to complete horizontal rows.
A simple chain reaction should do the trick here.
Unlike Puzzle mode, you can only choose a stage that you've reached normally here. For what I want to do next, I'm just going to go back to stage 1.
50 points is all that's needed to beat the default high score, but you can usually do way better than that! I was playing around and still got 75 here!
And yet, somehow, all those explosions missed a block, but that's fine. I wasn't ready to leave the stage yet, anyway.
Oh yeah! A 7-combo into a big bomb will have its explosion going the entire height of the field!
Oh, yeah. There's another way blocks can be removed. You might've seen minor occurrances of this earlier.
*Cackles maniacally* However, the bombs' explosions didn't reach most of the right side of the field. If only there was a way to increase the range of the bombs...
Okay, check this out!
Here's another new type of block. The darker blocks take two separate explosions to destroy, and they stop the explosion from advancing past them on the first hit. Still, this puzzle is very easy.
Well, maybe that wasn't a very good example, but you should've seen a few blocks and a bomb simply vanish right there.
Okay, here we go!
That range was absolutely huge! It went 9 spaces vertically, and across the entire board horizontally! Also, that range increases further with multiple line clears!
Those dark blocks were exiled to the cleft of dimension!
The usefulness of that may be limited in Contest mode, but it is important to know that in Puzzle mode. Speaking of which, I think I'll head over there and explain Puzzle mode now.
Well, I hope anyone that was confused in the slightest about Sparkliss has a better understanding of it now!
Cool, but it didn't quite clear everything...
No, actually. These placements are intentional!
Occasionally, you'll be given a piece made entirely of bombs. This could be fun!
However, depending on where the bombs are placed, you might not clear the entire row that was just made, and end up with something like this.
There we go! Well, I'm not going to go solve every single puzzle in the game.
However, it's not exactly the same. The bombs exploded in a cross shape, sort of like in Bomberman.
This all-bomb piece won't help for this. I'll just stick it up here for now. It'll be easy to blow up later.
Uh, oh. Did my ZSNES recording desynch again?
Now, you start with 100 points, and you lose one for each piece you use, and you gain one whenever you construct a big bomb. But, are there any other methods to increase your score?
Well, normally, a single bomb's explosion will reach 3 spaces in all four directions. However...
Oh, yeah. If four bombs form a 2x2 square, they'll become a large bomb. I'll cover that more in a moment. Right now, I'm still discussing the small bomb's range...
Also, I'm well set up for a triple early on! This ought to be fun!
Now, just like in Magicaliss, it's possible to create chain reactions if you're clever. Hmm... How would I create one here?
Oops... I guess that wasn't the solution...
Right now, I'm trying to put together a good example of what I'm talking about here.
Er... what? No boom? Yeah, if you form a line without any bombs in it, nothing will explode. However, that line will still count towards whatever combo you make next, so it can still be useful!
